notes: modal verb; highly irregular; used with auxiliary avere; past participle potuto
example_sentence_english: I want to be able to leave.

notes: gerund form; usually followed by an infinitive
example_sentence_english: Not being able to enter we wait outside.

notes: past participle; used with auxiliary avere + infinitive
example_sentence_english: I was able to do it.

notes: past participle; agreement may occur with preceding direct object pronoun
example_sentence_english: I was able to see her.

notes: past participle; agreement may occur with preceding direct object pronoun
example_sentence_english: I was able to help them.

notes: past participle; agreement may occur with preceding direct object pronoun
example_sentence_english: I was able to invite them.
I can come tomorrow.
You can call me later.
He can wait a moment.
We can go out early.
You can sit here.
They can start now.
I could run faster.
You could see the sea.
He could finish early.
We could help you.
You could arrive earlier.
They could understand everything.

notes: used with auxiliary avere; usually followed by an infinitive
example_sentence_english: I have been able to talk to him.

notes: used with auxiliary avere; usually followed by an infinitive
example_sentence_english: You have been able to sleep.

translation_english: he has been able to/she has been able to/you (formal) have been able to
notes: used with auxiliary avere; also used as formal Lei
example_sentence_english: He has been able to enter.

notes: used with auxiliary avere; usually followed by an infinitive
example_sentence_english: We have been able to see everything.

notes: used with auxiliary avere; usually followed by an infinitive
example_sentence_english: You have been able to finish.

notes: used with auxiliary avere; usually followed by an infinitive
example_sentence_english: They have been able to leave.
